bb.util
Class StringUtil

java.lang.Object
  bb.util.StringUtil

public final class StringUtil
extends Object

Provides various static String (and sometimes char[]) utility methods.

This class is multithread safe: it is immutable (both its immediate state, as well as the deep state of its fields).

Author:
Brent Boyer

Field Detail

newline

public static final String newline
Platform's standard for the char sequence that should separate lines. Is assigned by a call to System.getProperty("line.separator"). See this wikipedia entry for more discussion.

A regex which matches Pattern's line terminators.

Method Detail

inspectStringConstructor

private static boolean inspectStringConstructor()

newString

public static String newString(String s)
Immediately returns null if s == null. Otherwise, returns a new String instance whose underlying char[] precisely represents the chars of s (i.e. the length of the underlying char[] equals the length of s, there is no baggage). This guarantees that the result uses no more memory than required.

This minimal memory guarantee can be crucial in many situations. For example, consider the case of a String which was parsed as a substring from a long line of text from some file. Then a reference to all the chars of the original line of text must be maintained because of how the substring method operates, and so excess memory is used.

bytesToChars

public static char[] bytesToChars(byte[] bytes)
                           throws IllegalArgumentException,
                                  MalformedInputException,
                                  UnmappableCharacterException,
                                  CharacterCodingException
Converts bytes into a char[] which is returned.

The conversion is done using a new CharsetDecoder created from this platform's default Charset. Strict conversion mode is used (i.e. all errors result in Exceptions; no char substitutions or other silent error handling is performed). So, bytes must be perfectly encoded using this platform's default encoding.

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if bytes is null
MalformedInputException - if an illegal byte sequence for this charset is encountered
UnmappableCharacterException - if a byte sequence is encountered which cannot be mapped to an equivalent character sequence
CharacterCodingException - if a decoding problem occurs

equals

public static boolean equals(String s1,
                             String s2)
Determines whether or not s1 is equal to s2. The motivation for this method is that it correctly handles nulls, which frees the user from having to do that repetitive check. Specifically, it first checks for s1 == null, and if that is true returns the value of s2 == null). Otherwise, if s1 is not null, then it returns s1.equals(s2).

equalChars

public static boolean equalChars(char[] chars,
                                 String s)
Determines whether a char[] has exactly the same chars as a String. If one of the args, is null, then the other must be null as well for true to be returned.

toLength

public static String toLength(int number,
                              int length)
                       throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns a String which represents number and consists of exactly length digits, with leading 0's padded if necessary.

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if number is such that it cannot be represented by length digits

toLength

public static String toLength(String s,
                              int length,
                              boolean prepend,
                              char c)
                       throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns a String of exactly length chars. If s.length() == length, then s is returned. Otherwise, c is added to s enough times to make the result have length chars. If prepend is true, then c prepended to s, else it is appended.

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s == null; s.length() > length

repeatChars

public static String repeatChars(char c,
                                 int length)
                          throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns a String of the specified length which consists of entirely of the char c.

Contract: the result is never null, but will be empty if length = 0.

Parameters:
length - the number of chars in the result
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if length is negative

getTabs

public static String getTabs(int numberTabs)
                      throws IllegalArgumentException
Convenience method that returns the equivalent of repeatChars('\t', numberTabs). (For top performance, when numberTabs is small, which it usually is, this method returns an appropriate String constant. Otherwise, it makes a call to repeatChars.) One use is to create indentation levels when formatting output.

Parameters:
numberTabs - the number of tab chars in the result
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if numberTabs is negative

keepWithinLength

public static String keepWithinLength(String s,
                                      int limitLength)
                               throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns s if its length is less than limitLength. Otherwise tries to return as much from both the beginning and end of s as it can with an ellipsis "..." in the middle of the result to indicate that the middle was cut out. For example, keepWithinLength("abcdefghi", 7) returns "ab...hi".

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s == null; limitLength < 5

arraysToTextColumns

public static String arraysToTextColumns(double[][] arrays,
                                         String[] header)
                                  throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns a String representation of arrays as a series of text columns.

Since arrays is a double[][], then arrays[0], arrays[1], etc are double[] subarrays. The result takes each subarray and uses it as a column of text: arrays[0] is the first column, arrays[1] is the second column, etc.

Each row of the result is tab delimited: tab chars separate the numbers from each other. Note that the subarrays need not have equal length: this method will simply leave blanks in cells that have no data.

The header arg is optional (may be null), but if present, must have the same length as the number of subarrays (i.e. arrays.length) because it will be used to label each column.

To illustrate, the following code 


        double[][] arrays = new double[][] {
                new double[] {1},
                new double[] {1, 2},
                new double[] {1, 2, 3}
        };
        String[] header = new String[] {"A", "B", "C"};
        System.out.println( arraysToTextColumns(arrays, header) );
produces this output: 

        A       B       C
        1.0     1.0     1.0
                        2.0     2.0
                                        3.0

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if arrays == null; header != null && header.length != arrays.length

toMatrix

public static String[][] toMatrix(CharSequence cs)
                           throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns toMatrix(cs, lineTerminatorPattern, spaceTabCommaPattern). So, this convenience version can parse CharSequences where the rows are either space, tab, or comma delimited.

Warning: s must use spaces, tabs, or commas only as delimiters; these characters cannot appear anywhere else (e.g. inside what the user thinks should be a token). This means that this method cannot parse CharSequences that come from, say, true CSV files (parsing these requires something more complicated; see this webpage).

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException

toMatrix

public static String[][] toMatrix(CharSequence cs,
                                  Pattern rowDelimiter,
                                  Pattern columnDelimiter)
                           throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns a matrix representation of cs. The result is always a rectangular matrix (i.e. every row has the same number of elements; nulls being appended if necessary).

Parameters:
cs - the CharSequence to be parsed
rowDelimiter - the regex used to split cs into rows
columnDelimiter - the regex used to split each row into column tokens
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if any arg is null

isAllAsciiChars

public static boolean isAllAsciiChars(String s)
                               throws IllegalArgumentException
Determines whether or not s consists exclusively of US-ASCII chars.

The implementation here scans thru the chars of s and returns false upon the first char encountered which is not an ASCII value. Only if no such char is encountered is true returned. Note: this algorithm safely handles all Unicode 4.0 code points, including all supplementary code points, which Java's UTF-16 encoding uses a surrogate pair (i.e. two consecutive chars) for.

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s is null

asciiBytesToChars

public static char[] asciiBytesToChars(byte[] bytes)
                                throws IllegalArgumentException
Converts each element of bytes to a char[] which is returned. Every element of bytes must be a US-ASCII byte (i.e. high bit must be 0, so the only permissible values are [0, 127]). This method is much faster than going thru the standard Java ASCII converter.

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if bytes == null; if bytes contains a non-ASCII byte (i.e. a negative value)

diagnoseProblem

                                      int i)
Meant for use just by asciiBytesToChars to provide a better diagnostic message to the user.

rankAsciiCharsByHammingDistance

Meant for use just by describeAsciiCharsByHammingDistance to provide a better diagnostic message to the user.

toStringAscii

public static String toStringAscii(String s)
                            throws IllegalArgumentException
Converts s into an equivalent String that consists solely of US-ASCII chars. Each char from s that is already a US-ASCII char is directly used in the result. All other chars are represented as a Java Unicode escape sequence (i.e. have the format \uXXXX where XXXX is the hexadecimal value of the char).

One use for this method is when a String must be printed, but it is possible that the char convertor will fail to represent certain chars.

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s == null

isBlank

public static boolean isBlank(String s)
Determines whether or not s is "blank" (i.e. is either null, zero-length, or solely consists of whitespace).

isTrimmable

public static boolean isTrimmable(String s)
Determines whether or not s is "trimmable" (i.e. either begins and/or ends with a whitespace char). In other words, it determines if a call to s.trim would return a result that differs from s. Special cases: if s is either null or zero-length, this method immediately returns false.

isNewLineEnd

public static boolean isNewLineEnd(String s)
                            throws IllegalArgumentException
This method determines whether or not the supplied String ends in a newline char.

The newline constant of this class is the newline char sequence that is used.

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s is null

ensureEndsInNewLine

public static String ensureEndsInNewLine(String s)
                                  throws IllegalArgumentException
This method returns the supplied String if it already ends in a newline char sequence. Otherwise, the result is a newline char sequence appended to the original.

The newline constant of this class is the newline char sequence that is used.

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s is null

                                  throws IllegalArgumentException
Performs whitespace normalization, as per the XML spec.

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s is null
See Also:
the HTML whitespace normalization spec, the XML whitespace normalization spec

indentLines

public static String indentLines(String s)
                          throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns indentLines(s, 1).

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s is null

indentLines

public static String indentLines(String s,
                                 int numberTabs)
                          throws IllegalArgumentException
Parses individual lines out of s by a call to parseLines(s, true). Then returns a new String which consists of the concatenation of every line after each line is first preceded with an indent equal to the number of tab chars specified by numberTabs.

The result is never empty. It contains at least numberTabs tab chars. It may or may not end with end of line sequence char(s), depending on whether or not s does.

Parameters:
s - the String to split into lines and indent
numberTabs - the number of tab chars to use in each line's indent
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s is null; numberTabs is negative

parseLines

public static String[] parseLines(String s)
                           throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns parseLines(s, false).

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s is null

parseLines

public static String[] parseLines(String s,
                                  boolean includeEol)
                           throws IllegalArgumentException
Parses individual lines out of s, which are collectively returned as String[].

The result is never empty. It contains exactly one element if s has no end of line sequences, which includes the special case that s is zero-length (i.e. ""). If includeEol == true, then the concatenating every element in the result (e.g. by calling toString(lines, "")) reconstitutes s exactly.

Parameters:
s - the String to split into lines
includeEol - specifies whether or not to include the end of line sequence char(s) in the lines
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s is null

initList

private static List<String> initList(String s)

nextCharNewline

private static boolean nextCharNewline(String s,
                                       int i)

splitByLiteral

public static List<String> splitByLiteral(String s,
                                          String delimiter,
                                          int n,
                                          boolean nIsExact)
                                   throws IllegalArgumentException
Splits s into tokens. These tokens are delimited by delimiter (one or more chars, always treated literally, and never included as part of a token).

Contract: the result is never empty. This includes the special case that s is the empty String "", in which case the result has a single element that is "". Furthermore, if nIsExact is true, then it is guaranteed to have exactly n elements. The result's type always implements RandomAccess, so its List.get(int) method will be about as fast as an array's access. Finally, the result should always be equivalent to calling String.split(delimiter, -1), assuming that delimiter contains no special chars so that it too would be treated literally by the regex, and that the String[] returned by String.split is compared element by element with the List returned by this method.

The reason why this method was written is because its literal treatment of delimiter allows a more optimized parsing algorithm to be used. (It is 3-4 times faster than String.split, and 2+ times faster than Pattern.split, results depending on the String to be split; see UnitTest.benchmark_splitByLiteral for details.)

Parameters:
s - the String to split into tokens
delimiter - the token delimiting chars
n - the expected number of tokens
nIsExact - if true, then s must contain exactly n tokens; if false, n is merely a hint that the implementation can use for optimization
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s == null; delimiter is null or zero-length; n < 1; nIsExact is true and s fails to split into exactly n tokens

splitByChar

public static List<String> splitByChar(String s,
                                       char delimiter,
                                       int n,
                                       boolean nIsExact)
                                throws IllegalArgumentException
Identical to splitByLiteral except that the token delimiter is restricted to a single char, which allows an even more optimized algorithm to be used. (It is 1.5-2 times faster than splitByLiteral; see UnitTest.benchmark_splitByChar for details.)

Parameters:
s - the String to split into tokens
delimiter - the token delimiting char
n - the expected number of tokens
nIsExact - if true, then s must contain exactly n tokens; if false, n is merely a hint that the implementation can use for optimization
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s == null; n < 1; nIsExact is true and s fails to split into exactly n tokens

quoteWhitespaceTokenize

public static String[] quoteWhitespaceTokenize(String source,
                                               boolean includeQuotes)
                                        throws IllegalArgumentException
This method breaks up the supplied String into tokens. Tokens are delimited either by a sequence of double quote (i.e. '"') chars, or by whitespace chars.

The procedure followed is to find the next occurring double quote char. The substring of all untokenized chars before that double quote char is then tokenized using whitespace chars as delimiters. Then, the next token is the substring which consists of all chars from the current double quote till the next double quote. This procedure is repeated until the source String is exhausted.

It is an error if the source String has an odd number of double quote chars (i.e. they must occur in pairs).

An example application of this method is to parse command lines. Here, command line arguments are normally separated by spaces. However, double quotes are used to enclose those args which have spaces inside them.

Parameters:
source - the String to be tokenized
includeQuotes - specifies whether or not to include double quote marks with those tokens that are delimted by them
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if source is null or if it contains an odd number of double quote chars

wsTokensize

private static void wsTokensize(String source,
                                List<String> tokens)

removeQuotes

public static String removeQuotes(String s,
                                  int lineNumber)
                           throws IllegalArgumentException,
                                  ParseException
This utility method removes a matching leading and trailing pair of quote marks, if present, from the supplied String and returns the substring inside the quotes. If no such pair of leading or trailing quotes are present, then the original String is returned.

Any leading and trailing quote marks must be either both single or both double quote chars in order to match.

Parameters:
lineNumber - the line number where the String was found; used only if throw a ParseException
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s is null, or lineNumber < 0
ParseException - if a leading but no matching trailing quote mark is present, or vice versa

                       throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns a String representation of array.

The result consists of the elements of array in sequence, with separator between each element.

IllegalArgumentException - if array == null; separator == null

toString

public static <T> String toString(T[] array,
                                  String separator)
                       throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns a String representation of array.

The result consists of the elements of array in sequence, with separator between each element. If any element == null, then it is represented by the text "null".

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if array == null; separator == null

toString

public static String toString(Collection<?> collection,
                              String separator)
                       throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns a String representation of collection.

The result consists of the elements of collection as returned by its Iterator, with separator between each element. If any element == null, then it is represented by the text "null".

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if collection == null; separator == null

toString

public static String toString(Map<?,?> map,
                              String separator)
                       throws IllegalArgumentException
Returns a String representation of map.

The result consists of map's key/value pairs, with separator between each pair. The keys are obtained by map's keySet Iterator, and the text " --> " appears between the key and its value. If any key or value == null, then it is represented by the text "null".

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if map == null; separator == null

toStringLiteral

public static String toStringLiteral(String s)
                              throws IllegalArgumentException
Converts a String into a series of chars that constitute a Java String literal. In particular, double quotes are placed at the beginning and end, and any special chars inside are properly escaped.

One use is that you could take the result and directly paste it into a Java source file. Another use for this method is to handle filepaths with spaces and '\' chars (which commonly occur in DOS).

Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if s == null
